verses.text: If someone is found slain in the land the Lord your God is giving you to possess, lying in the field, and it is not known who struck him,
verses.comment: Introduces the case of an unsolved murder in the land.

verses.text: then your elders and your judges shall go out and measure the distance from the slain man to the surrounding cities.
verses.comment: Maintains literal sense of elders/judges’ responsibility.

verses.text: The elders of the city that is nearest to the slain man shall take a heifer that has not been worked and that has not pulled in a yoke.
verses.comment: Notes the requirement for an unworked heifer (compare with the red heifer ritual, Num. 19).

verses.text: And the elders of that city shall bring the heifer down to a valley with running water, which has not been plowed or sown, and shall break the heifer’s neck there in the valley.
verses.comment: Breaking the neck is a ritual for atonement, not a typical sacrifice.

verses.text: Then the priests, the sons of Levi, shall come near, for the Lord your God has chosen them to minister to Him and to bless in the Lord’s name. By their word every dispute and every assault shall be settled.
verses.comment: Highlights priestly mediation in matters of law and ritual.

verses.text: All the elders of that city nearest to the slain man shall wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the valley.
verses.comment: Washing hands symbolizes innocence—see Pilate’s act (Matt 27:24).

verses.text: And they shall declare, ‘Our hands have not shed this blood, nor have our eyes seen it.’
verses.comment: A strong oath of innocence.

verses.text: Forgive, Lord, Your people Israel, whom You have redeemed, and do not let innocent blood be among Your people Israel. And the blood guilt shall be forgiven them.
verses.comment: Explicit prayer for atonement and cleansing.

verses.text: So you shall purge the guilt of innocent blood from among you, when you do what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.comment: Echoes earlier commands to purge bloodguilt.

verses.text: When you go out to war against your enemies, and the Lord your God gives them into your hand and you take them captive,
verses.comment: Begins regulations for warfare and captives.

verses.text: and you see among the captives a beautiful woman, and you are attracted to her and desire to take her as your wife,
verses.comment: Prescribes circumstances for marrying a captive woman.

verses.text: then you shall bring her into your house, and she shall shave her head and trim her nails.
verses.comment: Shaving and trimming—symbols of leaving her old life.

verses.text: She shall remove the clothes of her captivity and stay in your house and lament her father and her mother a full month. After that, you may go in to her and be her husband, and she shall be your wife.
verses.comment: One month of mourning is a humane delay before marriage.

verses.text: But if you no longer delight in her, you shall let her go where she wishes. But you shall not sell her for money, nor shall you treat her as a slave, because you have humbled her.
verses.comment: Prohibits selling her—acknowledging dignity after marriage.

verses.text: If a man has two wives, the one loved and the other unloved, and both the loved and the unloved have borne him sons, and if the firstborn son belongs to the unloved woman,
verses.comment: Issue of inheritance between loved and unloved wives’ sons.

verses.text: then on the day when he assigns his sons their inheritance, he may not treat the son of the loved as the firstborn instead of the son of the unloved, the actual firstborn.
verses.comment: Forbids changing firstborn rights on grounds of affection.

verses.text: But he shall acknowledge the son of the unloved as the firstborn by giving him a double portion of all he has, for he is the beginning of his strength. The right of the firstborn is his.
verses.comment: ‘Double portion’ means a twofold share.

verses.text: If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who will not obey the voice of his father or the voice of his mother, and, though they discipline him, will not listen to them,
verses.comment: Describes a case of chronic disobedience.

verses.text: then his father and his mother shall take hold of him and bring him out to the elders of his city at the gate of the place where he lives.
verses.comment: The city gate was the place of legal decisions.

verses.text: And they shall say to the elders of his city, ‘This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious; he will not obey our voice; he is a glutton and a drunkard.’
verses.comment: Disobedience and dissolute behavior are cited.

verses.text: Then all the men of his city shall stone him with stones, so that he dies. So you shall purge the evil from among you, and all Israel shall hear and fear.
verses.comment: Public execution intended as warning and deterrent.

verses.text: And if a man has committed a sin deserving of death and he is put to death, and you hang him on a tree,
verses.comment: 'Tree' refers to impaling or exposure after execution.

verses.text: his body shall not remain all night on the tree, but you shall surely bury him the same day, for anyone who is hanged is cursed of God. You must not defile your land that the Lord your God is giving you for an inheritance.
verses.comment: Paul references this verse in Galatians about Christ becoming a curse for us.
